header.title: SEPHER MAPHTEAḤ SHELOMO (BOOK OF THE KEY OF SOLOMON)

central_thesis: The 'Sepher Maphteaḥ Shelomo' presents itself as an authentic Hebrew rendition of the legendary 'Key of Solomon,' providing comprehensive instructions for ceremonial magic. Its core purpose is to enable the practitioner to summon and command various spirits (angelic and elemental) to achieve practical ends, such as obtaining knowledge, wealth, protection, or influence, through a meticulously detailed system of prayers, invocations, consecrations, and the construction of magical tools and talismans, all framed within a monotheistic (Jewish) theological context.

structure_content.summary: This section by Hermann Gollancz contextualizes the Hebrew manuscript, noting its unique position among other 'Key of Solomon' versions (like the Latin 'Clavicula Salomonis'). It highlights the historical significance of this specific Hebrew text as a potential primary source or a parallel tradition, emphasizing its rigorous scholarly production as a facsimile for the first time.

Details numerous preparatory prayers, including the 'First Prayer' and 'Second Prayer' (Monoun/O Witness!), and 'Third Prayer' (Tetragrammaton). These establish a devotional framework, invoking divine authority and blessing for the magician's work. It also includes specific prayers for purification ('Ablution') and before donning ritual garments.

Extensive instructions are given for purifying the magician and consecrating all magical instruments. This includes the preparation of the magical knife, sword, sickle, pen, ink, virgin parchment, water, hyssop, lights, fire, and ritual garments. Specific, and sometimes unusual, ingredients like 'blood of the bat' are mentioned, along with instructions for a 'whistling-instrument' and a specialized altar called the 'Almadel.' Ritual purity is paramount throughout these preparations.

This part details the celestial influences crucial for successful operations. It covers planetary correspondences (days, hours, colors), lunar mansions (twenty-eight stations of the Moon), and their associated angels and seals. This highlights the grimoire's integration of astrological timing and angelic hierarchies to align magical work with potent cosmic energies.

Provides the core operative mechanics, including general conjurations and specific invocations for both angelic and elemental spirits. It outlines the process for drawing spirits into the 'Magic Circle,' obtaining responses, binding them into rings, and employing them for various purposes. The text explicitly names numerous spirits (e.g., 'SHANSHON,' 'SHANAUN') and provides their seals.

Focuses on the creation, illustration, and consecration of various magical seals and talismans (e.g., the 'nine Kandariṛi'). These diagrams, often incorporating divine and angelic names, are essential for protection, influence, and directing spiritual energies. Illustrations of the magic circle and other diagrams are integral to these practices.

Outlines a wide array of practical magical applications, ranging from scrying ('seeing a spirit in a mirror'), obtaining love ('recipe for love'), finding lost items ('discover theft'), influencing authority ('petition a lord or chief'), to more baneful magic ('injuring an enemy'). A notable section, 'The Operation of Simon Magus,' connects this Solomonic tradition to other magical currents, suggesting a broader historical tapestry of magical transmission.

Contains additional operations and conjurations for specific needs, such as healing 'malady of the eyes,' antidotes for 'swallowed poison,' and 'to coerce a king or ruler.' These illustrate the diverse, practical, and often personal nature of the magical requests addressed by the system.

key_concepts.definition: A foundational grimoire tradition focused on the summoning and commanding of spirits (both angelic and elemental) for various practical ends. This particular 'Sepher Maphteaḥ Shelomo' is presented as a Hebrew version of this tradition, potentially an antecedent or parallel development to more commonly known Latin and vernacular versions.

The distinct characteristic of this manuscript as being written in Hebrew, suggesting a direct link to Jewish esoteric and Kabbalistic traditions. The editor, Hermann Gollancz, emphasizes its significance as a Hebrew 'original book of magic' which influences its terminology, divine names, and specific ritual components.

A paramount principle in the system, involving meticulous ablutions, prayers, and blessings for the practitioner, the ritual space (e.g., the 'Magic Circle'), and all magical tools and materials. This purificatory process is believed to render the practitioner and their instruments suitable vessels for interacting with divine and spiritual forces.

The system extensively integrates planetary hours, days, colors, and associated angelic names and seals for determining auspicious timing and drawing down specific celestial influences. This hierarchical cosmology, including angels that 'minister before BOAL (BOEL)' and those of the 'twelve stations,' is central to the operational success of the magic.

Carefully constructed diagrams, often incorporating divine and angelic names, sigils, and geometrical forms, drawn on consecrated materials (like virgin parchment). These serve as focal points for spiritual energy, protective devices, or direct commands to spirits, being activated through specific prayers and rituals.

A specific ritual sequence mentioned in the Table of Contents, which indicates a connection to other magical currents beyond a purely Solomonic attribution. This suggests a potential syncretism or influence from earlier Gnostic or Hellenistic magical traditions, making the manuscript particularly interesting for historical analysis of magical lineages.

practical_system.description: The 'Sepher Maphteaḥ Shelomo' outlines a comprehensive system of ritual magic centered on commanding spiritual entities through divine authority. The operations are highly ritualized, emphasizing strict adherence to personal and instrumental purity, precise astrological timing, and the correct recitation of divine and angelic names. The magician, acting under the aegis of God (often referred to as the 'Great Prince'), seeks to compel spirits to manifest and perform specific tasks, ranging from revealing hidden knowledge to influencing worldly affairs. The system stresses the importance of consecrated tools, protective circles, and meticulously crafted talismans as conduits and controls for magical power.
tools: Magical Knife and Sword (for commanding and banishing)
Censer and Incense (for fumigation and offering)
Candles and Fire (for illumination and elemental presence)
Magical Pen and Ink (often specially prepared, for inscribing seals and diagrams)
Virgin Parchment (as a clean medium for talismans and writing)
Ritual Garments (for ritual purity and authority)
The Magic Circle (for protection and containing invoked entities)
Talismans and Seals (crafted diagrams for specific magical effects)
The Almadel (a specialized magical altar or tablet)
Whistling-instrument (a unique tool for spirit communication or command)
Magical Rings (for spirit containment and control)
rituals: Extensive ablutions and devotional prayers for personal purification and to invoke divine authority and protection.
Consecration of all magical implements and materials, including knives, swords, pens, inks, parchments, and ritual garments, through specific prayers and fumigations.
Construction and sanctification of the Magic Circle, serving as both a protective barrier for the operator and a focal point for the operation.
Precise timing of operations according to planetary hours, days, and lunar phases to align with specific celestial intelligences.
Recitation of complex invocations and conjurations using powerful divine names (e.g., TETRAGRAMMATON), angelic names, and specific commanding formulas to call forth spirits.
Creation and charging of talismans and seals, which are inscribed with magical characters, names, and diagrams, often made on virgin parchment.
Specific rituals for scrying (e.g., 'seeing a spirit in a mirror'), spirit containment (e.g., 'keeping a spirit shut up in a ring'), and banishing procedures.
Operations dedicated to practical outcomes such as healing, finding lost articles, securing love, gaining influence, or cursing enemies.

relevant_quotes.text: SEPHER MAPHTEAḤ SHELOMO (BOOK OF THE KEY OF SOLOMON) AN EXACT FACSIMILE OF AN ORIGINAL BOOK OF MAGIC IN HEBREW WITH ILLUSTRATIONS NOW PRODUCED FOR THE FIRST TIME

MONOUN (probably means O Witness!) O Lord, Holy One, Father of Power, God of the universe, before whom are all the created ones and the uncreated... Grant unto me thy actions this day Thy blessing and the confirmation of thy watchfulness; and may Thy holy revelation serve to enlighten me. Amen!

To overpower a king or ruler, and to overgrow and overpower thee, to do thy will. Before all things wash thy face, hands, and feet; read the Shema (i.e. Deut. vi. 4); then stand on thy left foot, and repeat three times this Conjuration: 'I call upon you, ye demons, who are appointed to coerce humankind, whose names are SHANSHON, SHANAUN, SHAGDIBEL, SANODEL, TALPALLI, YVUTHRA, IḤSHIR, ARBANIEL, Etc.'

The Magic Art was looked upon as a serious occupation, and was kept as an exclusive possession, may be gauged from the paragraph (fol. 6 b) containing the following regulation or order: 'Solomon remarks by Divine inspiration: God alone is One, and there is one Faith only—the exalted one which the Creator desired to be revealed unto mankind...'

critical_analysis.relevance: This facsimile holds immense relevance as a foundational primary source for understanding the Hebrew roots and variations of the Solomonic magical tradition. It significantly contributes to the study of Jewish esoteric practices, potentially predating or paralleling later European grimoires. Its unique content, including detailed Hebrew prayers and an 'Operation of Simon Magus,' provides crucial insights into the cross-cultural and historical development of Western ceremonial magic, offering a unique lens into the operative mechanics and underlying cosmology of these influential traditions.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience comprises academic scholars of Western Esotericism, Occult History, and Jewish Mysticism, who will find its Hebrew text and extensive notes invaluable for research. Additionally, serious practitioners of ceremonial magic, particularly those interested in traditional Solomonic grimoire work and its historical authenticities, will find this a vital manual. Its technical nature and reliance on historical-linguistic context make it less suitable for casual readers or beginners in magic.
